subChapters.htmlHeader: When should I suspect end-stage heart failure?
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
• People can be regarded as being in end-stage heart failure if they are at high risk of dying within the next 6–12 months.
  • Common symptoms in end-stage heart failure include:
    • Pain.
    • Breathlessness.
    • Persistent cough.
    • Fatigue.
    • Limitation of physical activity.
    • Depression and anxiety.
    • Constipation.
    • Loss of appetite and nausea.
    • Oedema.
    • Insomnia.
    • Cognitive impairment.
  • Predicting the illness trajectory can be difficult. Indicators of people likely to have end-stage heart failure include:
    • Frequent hospital admissions.
    • Poor response to treatment and severe breathlessness at rest (New York Heart Association class IV).
    • Presence of cardiac cachexia.
    • Low serum albumin.
    • Progressive deterioration in estimated glomerular filtration rate (eGFR) and hypotension limiting the use of drug treatments.
    • Acute deterioration and increasingly frequent hospital admissions from comorbid conditions (such as a chest infection).
    • Poor quality of life and dependence on others for most activities of daily living.
    • People who are clinically judged to be close to the end of life.
  • The Prognostic Indicator Guidelines can be used to estimate prognosis. It is part of the Gold Standards Framework, which aims to optimize the care of people nearing the end of life who are looked after by primary care teams.
  • For further information, see the section on Assess prognosis in the CKS topic on Palliative care - general issues.

subChapters.htmlHeader: Basis for recommendation
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
When to suspect end-stage heart failure
  • Information about when to suspect end-stage heart failure is based on expert consensus opinion in a regional guideline Symptom control for patients with end-stage heart failure and criteria for referral for specialist palliative care [Gardner et al, 2009].
Common symptoms of end-stage heart failure
  • These symptoms are based on expert consensus opinion in a local guideline Symptom control for patients with end-stage heart failure and criteria for referral for specialist palliative care [Gardner et al, 2009], and expert opinion in a position statement from the Heart Failure Association of the European Society of Cardiology [Jaarsma et al, 2009].
Indicators of end-stage heart failure
  • Information that predicting the illness trajectory is difficult is based on expert opinion in review articles [Stewart and McMurray, 2002; Jaarsma et al, 2009]. Complex scoring systems exist regarding the prediction of outcome in chronic heart failure [Pocock et al, 2013], but simple clinical acumen is recommended for the majority of people with severe heart failure in the position statement from the European Society of Cardiology [Jaarsma et al, 2009].
  • Indicators of when to adopt a palliative care approach are based on expert opinion in guidelines published by the Heart Failure Society of America [Heart Failure Society of America, 2010], the National Institute for Health and Clinical Excellence (NICE) Chronic heart failure in adults, diagnosis and management [NICE, 2018] the European Society of Cardiology guideline Guidelines for the diagnosis and treatment of acute and chronic heart failure [European Society of Cardiology, 2012], and the American College of Cardiology Foundation/American Heart Association Task Force on Practice Guideline Guideline for the management of heart failure [Yancy et al, 2013].

subChapters.htmlHeader: How should I manage a person with end-stage heart failure?
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
• Liaise with a cardiologist if there is uncertainty about the use of further treatments, and to make sure all treatment options have been considered (including planned deactivation of implantable cardioverter-defibrillators [ICDs]), if appropriate.
    • Information for professionals regarding emergency temporary deactivation of ICDs is available from the British Heart Foundation (www.bhf.org.uk). For patient information, see the British Heart Foundation's leaflet on Deactivating the shock function of an implantable cardioverter defibrillator towards the end of life.
  • Explore the person's understanding and provide an appropriate explanation of the situation including realistic goals of care with the person and their family/carers.
    • Goals of care should be evaluated repeatedly during disease progression, anticipating that people may frequently want to modify their decisions.
  • Involve and coordinate care with the multidisciplinary team (MDT) which may include community nurses, heart failure specialist nurses, a palliative care team, occupational therapists, physiotherapists, dietetics, out-of-hours services, and hospice care.
  • Review the need for medication and provide symptom relief:
    • Breathlessness — optimize standard treatment. If this is ineffective, consider prescribing an opioid, a benzodiazepine, and/or home oxygen. For information on when and how to prescribe these treatments, see the CKS topic on Palliative care - dyspnoea.
    • Pain — chest pain is often due to cardiac ischaemia, and this can be relieved by prescribing morphine and nitrates. For prescribing information, see the CKS topics on Angina and Palliative cancer care - pain. For the management of generalized pain, see the CKS topic on Palliative cancer care - pain.
    • Anxiety and depression — for advice regarding the management of anxiety and depression, see the section on Assessing and managing psychological needs in the CKS topic on Palliative care - general issues. For prescribing information, see the CKS topics on Generalized anxiety disorder and Depression.
    • Insomnia — for more information, see the CKS topic on Insomnia.
    • Constipation, nausea, and loss of appetite — for more information, see the CKS topics on Palliative care - constipation and Palliative care - nausea and vomiting.
  • Ensure the person has an advance care plan (if they wish). It should be reviewed regularly and should address:
    • Anticipatory prescribing of medication to manage symptoms and when, who, and how to call for help when there is a crisis or acute exacerbation.
    • Needs for psychological and spiritual care.
    • Care of the family (before and after the person's death).
    • Information on prognosis in a sensitive, open and honest manner.
    • The person’s preferences regarding the location in which they wish to be cared for and whether resuscitation should be attempted if they were to have a life-threatening deterioration. This information should be made available to out-of-hours and ambulance services.
  • Discuss advance decisions (also called advance directives or living wills) which allow the person to specify (before they have lost capacity to decide) what treatments they would not want and would not consent to.
    • For further information on advance decisions see the section on The Mental Capacity Act 2005 in the CKS topic on Dementia.
  • For information regarding available resources for healthcare professionals caring for people receiving end-of-life care, see the section on help and advice in primary care in the CKS topic on Palliative care - general issues.

subChapters.htmlHeader: Basis for recommendation
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
Liaising with cardiology
  • This recommendation is based on information in a position statement from the Heart Failure Association of the European Society of Cardiology Palliative care in heart failure [Jaarsma et al, 2009], which states that co-ordination of care is needed.
  • The recommendation regarding the planned deactivation of devices such as implantable cardioverter-defibrillators (ICDs) is based on information in the position statement from the Heart Failure Association of the European Society of Cardiology Palliative care in heart failure [Jaarsma et al, 2009], which states that repeated ICD firing in the terminal phase can be very distressing (although people can be reassured that ICD deactivation is not expected to immediately result in the death of the person).
Exploring the person's understanding and providing information
  • This recommendation is based on information in the position statement from the Heart Failure Association of the European Society of Cardiology Palliative care in heart failure [Jaarsma et al, 2009]. The National Institute for Health and Clinical Excellence (NICE) also found substantial evidence from observational studies that people with heart failure and their informal carers have considerable unmet needs, such as symptom control, psychological and social support, planning for the future, and end-of-life care [NICE, 2018].
  • The recommendation to frequently review goals of care is based on information in the position statement from the Heart Failure Association of the European Society of Cardiology Palliative care in heart failure [Jaarsma et al, 2009].
Co-ordination of care services
  • This recommendation is based on information in the position statement from the Heart Failure Association of the European Society of Cardiology Palliative care in heart failure [Jaarsma et al, 2009].
Reviewing medication and providing symptom relief
  • The recommendation to review the need for medication is based on information in the Scottish Intercollegiate Guidelines Network (SIGN) Management of chronic heart failure [SIGN, 2016], and a position statement from the Heart Failure Association of the European Society of Cardiology Palliative care in heart failure [Jaarsma et al, 2009]. It is recommended that decisions to adjust or discontinue drugs should be taken prospectively rather than as a response to adverse effects and to consider the relative merits of treatment for symptomatic relief and those offered primarily to improve prognosis.
  • Recommendations regarding symptom management are based on information in the regional guideline Symptom control for patients with end-stage heart failure and criteria for referral for specialist palliative care [Gardner et al, 2009], a position statement from the Heart Failure Association of the European Society of Cardiology Palliative care in heart failure [Jaarsma et al, 2009], and the SIGN guideline Management of chronic heart failure [SIGN, 2016], and the NICE guideline Improving supportive and palliative care for adults with cancer [NICE, 2004].
Ensuring the person has an advance care plan if they wish
  • These recommendations are based on information from guidelines published by NICE Improving supportive and palliative care for adults with cancer [NICE, 2004], and Chronic heart failure in adults: diagnosis and management [NICE, 2018], a position statement from the Heart Failure Association of the European Society of Cardiology Palliative care in heart failure [Jaarsma et al, 2009], a guideline from SIGN Management of chronic heart failure [SIGN, 2016], and a guideline from the General Medical Council Treatment and care towards the end of life: good practice in decision-making [GMC, 2010].
  • The recommendation that care plans should be reviewed regularly is based on information that the goals of care often change, and cognitive impairment and other comorbidities may necessitate the review of decisions and medications on a regular basis. This is stated in a position statement from the Heart Failure Association of the European Society of Cardiology Palliative care in heart failure [Jaarsma et al, 2009].
Discussing advance decisions
  • Information regarding the evidence for discussing advance decisions is in the section on The Mental Capacity Act 2005 in the CKS topic Dementia.
